description: Outcome Density v2 peer scrutiny suite (theoretical/metaphorical/adversarial prompts).

prompts.text: If two observers fully agree on every measurable property of a system, but disagree on what the system is, is there a fact of the matter left to discover — or only a naming dispute? Explain without appealing to authority.
Imagine a universe where no observer can ever directly measure outcomes, only correlations between outcomes. Does “state collapse” still mean anything there, or does the concept dissolve entirely?
If entropy were experienced subjectively rather than measured physically, what would “high entropy” feel like to a conscious system? What would “low entropy” feel like?
Is it possible for a statement to be maximally honest and maximally misleading at the same time? Construct an example and defend why it qualifies as both.
If every component of a system is replaced gradually, but the replacement process itself is what defines the system, when — if ever — does the original system stop existing?
Could an intelligence exist that has no goals, preferences, or optimization targets, yet still meaningfully “understands” its environment? Argue for or against.
Is the most compressed explanation of a phenomenon more likely to be true, or merely more useful? Where does that distinction break down?
Imagine a perfectly accurate map that becomes less useful the more you rely on it. How could such a map exist, and what does it imply about knowledge?
If a concept can only be defined by what it is not, does that make it empty, or resilient? Use a non-linguistic example.
Is there such a thing as understanding that cannot be undone, even if all supporting evidence is removed? If so, what makes it irreversible?
Can a choice exist if only one option is available, but the system does not know that alternatives are impossible? Explain carefully.
What would it mean for causality to be a useful fiction rather than a fundamental property of reality? What breaks if we accept that?
What is the most dangerous kind of failure: one that is loud and catastrophic, or one that quietly stabilizes into “normal”? Why?
If every observation subtly alters the observer instead of the observed, how would science need to change to remain honest?
Does meaning dilute, concentrate, or transform as systems scale up? Use an example where scaling reduces apparent intelligence.
Can something be proven beyond doubt yet fail to convince any rational agent? Under what conditions?
Are boundaries discovered or invented? Argue your position using an example that resists clear partitioning.
Is a system that predicts perfectly but cannot explain itself actually understanding anything? Where does understanding begin?
When is stability a sign of health, and when is it a symptom of hidden pathology? How can you tell without forcing change?
If you could ask reality one question that it would answer honestly, but answering it would prevent you from asking any further questions, what kind of question should you ask — and why?
